title: 112_hr6659
content: The "Urban Recovery and Growth Act" is cited as the short title. It extends the Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds for certain cities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Urban Recovery and Growth Act" extends the Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds by treating them as qualified bonds issued before January 1, 2011. Interest on these bonds is taxable, and the term "economic development extension bond" refers to specified bonds issued within a 1-year period for qualified purposes. The term "specified bond" refers to any obligation, excluding private activity bonds, where the interest would be tax-exempt under section 103. The issuer must designate the bond for qualified purposes, and the excess amounts in a reserve must be used accordingly. The term "specified city" refers to principal cities with high unemployment rates that qualify for certain economic development purposes and refinancing of existing debt. The specified city must meet specific criteria to qualify for economic development purposes and debt refinancing, including having an average unemployment rate at least 150% higher than the national average and a population loss of at least 20% between 2000 and 2010. The maximum amount of bonds designated for a city is limited based on its population proportion to $1 billion. The bond limitation allocated to specified cities is based on their population proportion to $1 billion. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part III of subchapter Y of chapter 1 of the Code. Extension of recovery zone economic development bonds for certain cities, effective for obligations issued after the enactment of this Act.
